review.title: Normalization of Non-Standard Words in Croatian Texts
review.abstract: This paper presents text normalization which is an integral part of any text-to-speech synthesis system. Text normalization is a set of methods with a task to write non-standard words, like numbers, dates, times, abbreviations, acronyms and the most common symbols, in their full expanded form are presented. The whole taxonomy for classification of non-standard words in Croatian language together with rule-based normalization methods combined with a lookup dictionary are proposed. Achieved token rate for normalization of Croatian texts is 95%, where 80% of expanded words are in correct morphological form.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Speech synthesis systems perform the conversion of any input text into synthesized language [7]. These systems consist of various components that enable speech generation; one of the components of a TTS system is text normalization, which transforms non-standard text elements into their extended form and prepares them for further processing in the system (g2p conversion, prosody generation, etc.) In most cases, text normalization involves numbers, dates, time, abbreviations, acronyms, various symbols, currencies, units of measurement, etc. The first problem with text normalization is the recognition of non-standard words (NSW). Sometimes standard words and NSWs share the same font form - North Pole, Half, and Pole - / Political /. The second problem is to write the recognized NSWs in their fully extended form. For example, the first problem with text normalization is the recognition of non-standard words (NSW).

sections.heading: 2 Text Normalization
sections.text: Normalization is the first step in the word preprocessing of TTS [7]. The normalization module is responsible for the identification of a single NSW token and its transformation into extended form. Normally, NSWs are not listed in the dictionary and there is no clear rule for their expansion or pronunciation [12]. Also, they are more ambiguous than conventional words in meaning or pronunciation. The first problem is to identify all NSWs in Croatian and separate them from standard words. The second problem is the transformation of recognized NSW into extended form, fitting the TTS system. These two problems are the most obvious, but there are some other problems to consider. For example: When does punctuation mark the end of a sentence, and when is an abbreviation? For example, in the sentence "Ivo je na natjecanju bio 3. i odlikovan je broncom." would we recognize the number / 3. / as "the third" But like this two sentences, the computer cannot recognize one and two?

sections.heading: 3 Taxonomy of Normalization for Croatian Language
sections.text: In most TTS systems, the normalization of the text is achieved by using handwritten rules defined for specific fields of application [1,12], together with rules [16], n-gram models [7,12], decision trees and weighted finite state converters [12] or reference dictionaries (lists) of the most common NSWs with their extended form [12], these were used. Listing all NSWs is tedious and therefore never ensures the complete success of normalization, i.e. it does not guarantee that some novel NSW characters from the input text will also be listed in the reference dictionary. Therefore, we suggest that the taxonomy, which classifies all positive NSWs, provides the complete framework for text standardization for the Croatian language. First, the module classifies NSWs as letters, digits or combinations as shown in the main classification tree table 1. It is important that the textual rules are written strictly according to the proposed taxographic categories.

sections.text: The normative algorithms are implemented in Perl. Perl is suitable for word processing [11], because there are many automatic functions to solve problems of lexical analysis and functions for word processing. The proposed solution is based on the identification of NSW with regular expressions contained in the correct class of the tree. sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: This paper describes the normalization of non-standardized words in Croatian texts for the purpose of speech synthesis. Normalization of the text is highly complex if we take into account the determination of the correct gender, number and case of normalized words. Also, the problem is that input texts are not written completely according to the orthographic principles of the standard Croatian language and the text normalization module must have a certain degree of tolerance in the execution of its methods, which make the systems even more complex. Synthesized text is better and more complete if as many samples as possible are extended in the text pre-processing process. To this end, we proposed the taxonomy of croatical NSWs, which unifies the normalization procedures of Croatian texts. Algorithms for detecting samples for normalization (ordinary and cardinal numbers, data of numerical and combined forms, time, abbreviations, acronyms and symbols) and algorithms for normalization of forms, date and abbreviation forms (were constructed as date and normalities).
